title: Who will win the 2020 Bolivian presidential election?
possible_answers: No election will be held in 2020
preds: Hey @nonplus, @sebawi, @WBHumanoid, how did you know to ignore the polls for this question?
Interesting. The polls were wrong. The polls were massively wrong.
A stunning victory, long live the revolution / Una Victoria grandiosa, que viva la revolucion!

Well that’s it. Mesa concedes, despite having a clear lead in the official count, with only 20% tallied: https://twitter.com/carlosdmesag/status/1318211422577459200?s=21 Big lesson is there is a lot I do not understand about elections in places like Bolivia.
Not really buying the 'quick counts'. Right now 1.1m/7.3m votes are counted and Mesa is leading 43.8% to Arce's 35.2%

Putting 100 into Arce because I had earlier assumed Mesa would win (and apparently these preliminary results have enough weight that the current president is congratulating Arce), but I have to say I am very doubtful about these exit polls/quick counts. They are totally inconsistent with all opinion polling of recent months and it would seem they are also inconsistent with the official count as it now stands.
Closing polls also point toward comfortable lead for Arce https://m.dw.com/en/bolivian-election-exit-polls-show-socialist-candidate-ahead/a-55319676

Exit polls suggest win for Luis Arce.
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-54591963

Well, now it's looking like President Anez is declaring Arce the winner based on an exit poll: 
https://twitter.com/JeanineAnez/status/1318048552191483904
There's a lot I don't understand about Bolivia, apparently.
Vote count official results are still showing Mesa with a huge lead though?
https://computo.oep.org.bo/
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/18/bolivia-votes-in-high-stakes-presidential-election-amid-pandemic _First quick count points toward clear Ace win >50%

Calling it for Mesa, most likely in Round 1.  Arce has significantly underperformed just about everywhere except with Bolivians abroad. Chuquisaca with 10% in now and massive underperformance by MAS is sustained. Barring some enormous change, this thing is a foregone conclusion.

Vote counting will take several days, but comparing results with 2019, I would definitely want to be Mesa right now. For example, Chuquisaca province, his party won by only 2 points in 2019. Right now he's up by 55!
Compared with 2019, initial CC results looking good and MAS not so good. Bumping this up again. Still a little uncertainty. Official count here: https://computo.oep.org.bo
Initial results looking favorable for Mesa, compared with Evo Morales results.
Two realistic candidates remain, Mesa is up a little in 2 recent polls, Arce is up big in 2 others. Difficult to name a clear frontrunner, but I give Arce the edge here.

Candidacy of María Bayá, of the conservative Nationalist Democratic Action Party, is withdrawn on eve of election. Another 50-100 basis points of the electorate is now going to the anti-MAS vote. Bumping up odds of Carlos Mesa accordingly.  Looking at the polling, Arce has never polled above 42.2%. He is the only one in his ideological lane and has been from the start. Looking at past elections, Bolivia has more elastic voters than the United States, but Arce's main hope for tomorrow is that the Mesa-Camacho voters are divided enough to give him the 1st round win.

For a win in the first round, a candidate needs to get more than 40% of the vote and 10% more than the opponent with the 2nd most votes [1,2]. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bolivia-election-polls-idUSKBN26739R
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Bolivian_general_election#Second_round
Small insanity to pick political winners in a place you've never even visited. I'll go sit on the fence for the rest of the week.

Jorge Quiroga has dropped out. Though he was polling at only about 2%, these will all go to the anti-MAS vote, making it that much more likely that Arce doesn't win the 1st round. Bumping up Mesa's odds.  https://www.canberratimes.com.au/story/6964600/bolivian-ex-leader-out-of-president-vote/?cs=14232

Bumping this one up based on further learning about the parties and candidates. It's MAS vs. an array of anti-MAS candidates.  The only way Arce is winning this is if he gets +10 in Round 1. No polling is showing that, and no movement in the polling is showing that. If no winner in Round 1, this thing is 90% Mesa.
https://www.as-coa.org/articles/explainer-presidential-candidates-bolivias-2020-special-elections

New poll just dropped: https://erbol.com.bo/el-%C3%A1nfora-1/encuesta-ipsos-arce-lleva-delantera-en-primera-vuelta-y-mesa-se-perfila-en-eventual
1st round has Arce at 34, Mesa 28, Camacho 14. undecideds 19%. 
Runoff has Mesa at 45, Arce at 40, undecideds 15%

Comparing polling vs outcome in 2019: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Bolivian_general_election MAS outperformed polling average. Therefore bumping Arce up. I could be wrong though, because maybe pollsters have corrected the issues they had back then, or maybe the elections will be freer of irregularities than they were then.

As explained earlier, I find it quite likely that the election goes into a second round, at which point most of the Camacho and Anez voters would probably give their votes to Mesa instead of Arce. Voting in Bolivia is mandatory.

No Arce or Camacho at last night's debate: https://youtu.be/mtjpwHmzgb8?t=960 ... so advantage Mesa.
I'm not sure what I'm missing here. All indicators are this thing is going into a runoff, at which point the Camacho voters go for Mesa.
Final update. Cannot detect latest polls post September 2020 https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-09-16/bolivia-election-poll-suggests-outright-victory-for-morales-candidate

Another new poll , the 2nd post Anez dropout just released:
https://www.celag.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/informe-bolivia-oct-2020-web.pdf
Page 8 - Arce at 36.4%, Mesa at 27.9%, and Camacho at 12.5%. Arce close to the 10 points ahead of 2nd place finisher needed to avoid a runoff. 
Page 13 - In case of runoff, Mesa leads by 2.2 points
I'll take the "I don't know" position.
Americas Society article offers some background on Mesa...  https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/bolivia-has-changed-since-2003-has-carlos-mesa/   draw your own conclusions

>"La consulta realizada por Ciesmori muestra un 13,3% de personas que aún no tienen claro por cuál candidato se van a decantar. Mientras que un 8,4% de las personas encuestadas prefirieron no revelar cuál sería su elección. 4,3% de los consultados votarían en blanco y un 1,5% anularían su sufragio." Thanks to @Terry-Smith for the source! [1] https://www.paginasiete.bo/nacional/2020/9/30/encuesta-de-ciesmori-perfila-segunda-vuelta-entre-arce-mesa-269921.html
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1148546

Happy to be shown where I am wrong, but it looks like I'm going against the crowd here. New poll out, the first since Anez withdrew: https://www.paginasiete.bo/nacional/2020/9/30/encuesta-de-ciesmori-perfila-segunda-vuelta-entre-arce-mesa-269921.html  Although Arce is favored to win the first round, part of the poll asked about a hypothetical runoff between Arce and Mesa, which is the most likely outcome. Mesa is +7.2  There are still about 1 in 5 voters undecided between the two candidates, however, so a lot could happen.

Anez is still running the show and "liberal economic reforms" (Bolivian style) are causing shake rattle and roll, cabinet resignations (economy minister)...  link here https://en.mercopress.com/2020/10/01/privatization-policy-in-bolivia-divides-the-cabinet-and-triggers-several-ministerial-resignations?utm_source=feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_content=main&utm_campaign=rss&utm_source=MercoPress+Latest+News&utm_campaign=1064785b3b-RSS_EMAIL_CAMPAIGN&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_f95ead9f0a-1064785b3b-71648993 Doesn't seem like Arce's chances are getting any better.

Updating to reflect Anez's withdrawal as well as the fact that there has yet to be a poll I've seen with Mesa ahead of Arce. One is tied, a couple are close, and a few more are blowouts for Arce, but none have Mesa with any sort of lead (yet). While Undecided voters could swing it either way, it's never a good thing when a candidate has yet to come out ahead in major polling.
According to the wikipedia page, 40%+ of people would not vote on an Arce vs Mesa second round (??) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Bolivian_general_election#Second_round
I'll capitulate and weight Arce a little more.
With 4 weeks prior to election, I'll sit on the fence as I have no good data.
Based on the information that the 18 October re-election is still on the schedule, and about the new anti-MAS front.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/world/americas/bolivia-jeanine-anez.html
My Bolivian friend says this will allow the opposition to Evo Morales MAS party to consolidate. He says there might be a run-off and Mesa will win. I am going to readjust.

I think the crowd overestimates Arce a bit:
1) It may not be a purely democratic election (current executive branch is anti-Arce and there have been irregularities in Bolivia before)
2) there may be a round 2, in which anti-Arce elements unify
3) polls could be off in either direction.

With Jeanine Anez out of the race, a second election round becomes more likely (prior 50%) in which anti-MAS parties might join forces to elect Carlos Mesa https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/18/bolivia-president-jeanine-anez-evo-morales

I am a little slow at reading, but I see that Anez has withdrawn to avoid vote splitting. Good idea. So she is likely to ensure that a vote actually occurs on 10/18 as well and reducing the chances of anyone else winning the poll.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/world/americas/bolivia-jeanine-anez.html
Anez has pulled out due to low polling. Elections still schedule for 18 October.
NYT and other sources say she has "withdrawn"

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-54200843
Ms Anez quits the race to give Mesa a chance. Might not be enough, but slightly updates my previous forecast.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

According to W.H.O.'s table as of 13 September 2020 Bolivia (Plurinational State of) 125,172  967  7,250  57  Community transmission Bolivia's pandemic situation seems to be on the edge towards uncontrolled, with almost 1,000 cases per day and a total of 125,172 cases, the last 100,000 of which were reported in about 80 days since 24 June 2020 only. I can't imagine how an in-person election can happen safely in less than six weeks, just for the sake of some strange calculus that the Bolivian election MUST happen prior to the US election, unless they are willing to pay a very high prize with regards to infections (current growth rate: 0.77% per day, a second wave appears to be just starting), hospitalizations and ultimately increasing numbers of fatalities (currently 57 per day), and probably swivel to a growth path of Argentina or the likes. However, if it happens, Luis Arce seems to be in favor by a large margin, so I put this together into a bipolar forecast which neglects any chances of Anez or Mesa, but will considerably weight the chance of a further postponement or cancellation of the due election instead again.
I'll give the points to "someone else" from the "no election will be held" bucket and the remainder to Arce.

- I believe the chance of the elections happening in 2020 to be around 95% now
- I adjusted my probabilities after seeing recent polls which indicate a tight race between Arce and Mesa well ahead of Anez. The president is elected in a two-round election. If Arce does not get a majority in the first round (or 40% of the votes with >10% difference to Mesa), there will be a run-off election between Arce and Mesa. Quite a lot of uncertainty then comes from the question whether Anez and Camacho join forces with Mesa.  Sources: 
https://www.nytimes.com/es/2020/09/09/opinion/contributors/bolivia-socialism-arce-elections-morales.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Bolivian_general_election
Arce seems headed for the win.
I need to read up on this
Update on confirmation of election date.
With a little help from her "friends"...   link https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/09/04/facebook-bolivia-cls/?hpid=hp_world-right-4-0_world-latest-feed-magic2%3Ahomepage%2Fstory-ans
Oct 18 is only about 6 weeks away and Bolivia is still suffering from Covid-19.

visit the page. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Bolivian_general_election
2020   
and view the most recent polling data, back to Januar.  Scroll down to "second round" and note that in most recent polling by Mercados y Muestras former newscaster Anez, holds her own against Arce and Mesa.   If you read Spanish you can see the full article here on Pagina Siete https://www.paginasiete.bo/nacional/2020/8/18/se-amplia-la-brecha-entre-mesa-arce-en-un-eventual-balotaje-264902.html#!

Reduced value of Áñez on reports of Morales demanding she step down (https://www.ft.com/content/44cb787a-32e2-446c-b257-559bb60994e9)
Reduced value of "no election" on reports of confirmed election date.

The character assassination campaign directed at former president Evo Morales-- being conducted by the interim government of acting president Anez, namely her justice minister Alvaro Gamboa-- which characterizes the former leader of Bolivia's coca plant planters and gatherers as the equivalent of Woody Allen and Roman Polanski on steroids-- is bound to cause some collateral damage to the campaign of his hand picked "successor" Luis Arce. Here is a link from the lowland Santa Cruz de la Sierra daily (online and newsprint) El Deber  https://eldeber.com.bo/pais/anez-acusaciones-por-actos-de-pedofilia-son-imperdonables-y-no-quedaran-en-la-impunidad_197458     draw your own conclusions.   Another recent article in El Deber indicates that the Anez government has requested that Evo be put on the Interpol Red List for extradition.  But one can argue that Interpol and its Red List can often be problematic, and rife with credibility problems. A recent topper at Interpol in Lyon was called home to the PRC and seems to have disappeared. If one takes a deep dive, one will learn that since Anez became "the accidental interim president"  Bolivia has received the following...   $254 million from World Bank to mitigate economic impact of Covid-19... $327 million from IMF as emergency support to address Covid-19 economic issues, and a $450 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank to help the nation during the Covid-19 pandemia.  It is all there on Google.  From the way northern hemisphere MSM and NGOs are reporting, and scanning the LatAm press there isn't much indication that those funds are being used to help mitigate the pandemia in Bolvia. And the NYT has a particulary poignant take on that theme here- need to log in- https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/22/world/americas/virus-bolivia.html None of this bodes well for the  party still led by Evo. The loans and instruments were organized with the Anez interim government, which  is banked by a reorganized senior military establishment.  If you were "them" would you want to relinquish control over a billion dollars?
My Bolivian friend said the military ended to roadblocks and protests. Evo Morales has a big following and his man is Luis Acre.

Protesters are now demanding an election and are already annoyed with the October date that was just announced. Cases are still high but decreasing. Mesa has seemingly closed the gap with Arce, though only one poll has been taken recently so this could be an over-representation of his support. Too soon to tell, but as the situation stands it appears an election will be held in October barring any huge resurgence. Runoff scheduled for November means we should have a president announced before 2021.
Situation in Bolivia still dire. Over 100K Covid-19 cases with over 1200 new per day.

A couple of recent polls, one from France 24, do not examine the issue whether the oft posponed elections will not be held in 2020 and I think they will so I zeroed that option    linkhttps://www.france24.com/en/20200818-morales-ally-and-one-time-president-tied-in-bolivia-opinion-poll  The polls show almost "neck and neck" between Evo's candidate, Arce, and Mesa.  A former tv news personality with national name recognition he was elected VP back in 2002, and became interim president, a mediocre one at that, 2003-05.  Old school, not a pol who can repurpose or rebrand with the times to become a winner in 2020.  Anez, younger, does have those traits.  And it is her government that is amping up the ugly character assassination of Evo, which is now spilling over onto Arce.  This link from the Santa Cruz de la Sierra newspaper El Deber offers details.
 https://eldeber.com.bo/pais/gobierno-dice-que-arce-loza-y-rodriguez-deben-declarar-y-surge-una-segunda-denuncia-contra-evo-por-r_196889   This is the inerim president, Anez,  whose regime has enough power in Bolivia and outside to make this yellow press happen, btw, which is not likely to help a lukewarm candidate like Mesa.  Draw your own conclusions.  A lot of mainstream Dems, among them Susan Rice, would not be unhappy if the last vestiges of the "pink tide" in Bolivia faded into darkness.

El Deber, a leading newspaper in Bolivia' s largest city (around 2 million metro area), Santa Cruz de la Sierra, in the lowlands that border Brazil, published an article today in which the president of the Bolivian Catholic Bishops' Conference, Mons. Ricardo Ernesto Centellas Guzman, says (more or less, my translation)  "there are no guarantees of transparent elections considering who is administering the elections, and the silence of the judiciary in relation to the (electoral) fraud of (last) October."   Draw your own conclusions.  Acting president and former tv news presenter, Anez, has done some photo-ops holding a bible...  here is link in Spanish  https://eldeber.com.bo/pais/iglesia-alerta-que-no-hay-garantias-de-una-eleccion-transparente-con-el-actual-padron-electoral_196619
Bolivia is suffering from Covid-19 and from MAS voters who feel abandoned. Morales is attempting to direct his followers from Argentina. October 18 seems a long way off to all concerned.

Bolivia's legislature has approved the use of a "toxic bleach" as a remedy for Covid-19. Link https://www.businessinsider.com/bolivian-lower-house-approves-toxic-bleach-as-covid-19-treatment-2020-8

The statements being made by MAS leader and ex-president Morales, exiled in Argentina, can be seen as actually mobilizing opposition to his movement, and "his" candidate Arce, who really does not have exposure as a leader or influencer in Bolivia MSM nor on the nation's "low-fi" social media.  Clearly, Anez recognizing Guaido as president in VEN has earned her a modicum of support from Washington minions who want the former busdriver who seems to be still running VEN, thrown under the bus.  Considering how the "half moon" group of states Santa Cruz, Beni, Pando and Tarija, oppose the "centralization" that Arce will try to continue if he wins, and that Santa Cruz state alone, is the major economic powerhouse in Bolivia, Anez, who was a senator from "Half Moon" state Beni for a decade, might surprise... with a little help from her friends, the godfearing among them.

Thanks to @fisherdbus
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1107493 I now believe the Oct 2020 date will be fixed for at least the rest of August. Readjusting accordingly.

While I still believe that the plurinational state of Bolivia is not an exception in South America with regards to SARS-CoV-2 and the public health situation will deteriorate much faster than the current numbers suggest (any pathway between Chile and Argentina is possible), and I assume Bolivia is even less prepared to secure a fair and legal election process with a large share of mail-in ballots than the US, I prefer some re-adjustments for tactical reasons.
An election in October 2020 can of course be pushed through, but with likely fatal consequences in the aftermath and a high price in terms of death toll.

New election date is in October, which could be feasible, though there is still a chance it will be pushed back again. However, given the protests accompanying this delay, it is unlikely to be delayed without a large uptick in COVID cases directly before the election date. Currently cases are on the rise, with over 1,700 reported yesterday. If this continues, they may have no choice but to delay again, but the government has plenty of time and incentive to address the current conditions and hold the elections in October. With little chance of a run-off given current polls, there is a good chance someone will be elected in 2020.

Situation changing daily. WAPO (registration may be reqd) weigh in today 12 Aug with its own take  discussing increasing instability, suggesting that Anez is trying to hold on to power...  link https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/bolivia-protest-blockade-anez-evo-coronavirus/2020/08/11/7ffceb50-db48-11ea-809e-b8be57ba616e_story.html  In this context of instability, it is important to remember that the city of Santa Cruz de La Sierra is around 650 clicks from the frontier with Brazil, and is the capital of Santa Cruz state which, has an easily transited border with Brazil.  Santa Cruz de la Sierra the city has a metro area population of around 2 million, depending on who is counting, and is really the most influential city in Bolivia for a variety of reasons.  There, if you deep dive in Spanish language media you will find Arce is only hitting 36% popularity in latest polling in Santa Cruz de la Sierra and the entire state, which complements the Argentinan -Pulitzer winnner Andres Oppenheimer's piece in Miama Herald I posted earlier link-  https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/andres-oppenheimer/article244815042.html    in which he posits that a "second round" of voting will be needed to elect a "new president"....   Brazil has already lowered the amount of natural gas it has agreed to import from Bolivia by about one third, which means fewer dollars flowing into Bolivia.  Santa Cruz is a major supply chain hub and transshipment point for international coca trade which suggests other power players who are not "transparent"  may be active in this Kabuki-style political drama.
Reducing the chance that no election will be held. Bolivia has about 90K cases with roughly 1K new per day. Unclear if Covid-19 will force an early or late election.

According to Montivedo based (and sometimes pro-British with respect to Falklands-South Atlantik) "Mercopress" online news service-- Bolivia senior military now speaking out about threat to "national security" gracias a Arce-Evo crew blockading areas around "capital" of La Paz and its poor suburbs, allegedly disrupting shipments of oxygen to health centers, and fomenting the delay in the voting. They are calling for election as soon as possible.  Link  https://en.mercopress.com/2020/08/11/bolivia-s-military-and-police-called-on-political-leaders-to-dialogue-and-lift-blockades?utm_source=feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_content=main&utm_campaign=rss&utm_source=MercoPress+Latest+News&utm_campaign=8315ed3422-RSS_EMAIL_CAMPAIGN&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_f95ead9f0a-8315ed3422-71648993 Bolivia has been complacent regarding the appointment of Brazilian sinophobe and former education minister, Weinberg,  to a directorship albeit short term) at the World Bank, which was supported by Washington. Also likely current covernment will support US choice of Claver-Carone to head Interamerican Development Bank, the first gringo in history to run the organization- the vote happens in a few weeks. Pulitzer winner and Argentinian Andres Oppenheimer has a few things to say about Claver-Carone in the Miami Herald (Argentina opposes him) crafting his op-ed into a "Biden vs Trump" piece.  Link https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/andres-oppenheimer/article244741837.html All of this suggests the pressure to hold election in Bolivia to be held before the official US election day in November, is increasing.

Playing defense vs the crowd.
Memories are short, my initial assessment stands: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1086715

Arce's crowd has been making a lot of noise lately, according to Guardian link https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/09/bolivia-protesters-bring-country-to-standstill-over-election-delays-covid-19-evo-morales Clearly Washington nor its friends in the extractive industries do not want to see another Evo-style leader running Bolivia.  Unlikely staunch Trump ally Brazil wants a "commo" like Arce running things either. The public health infrastructure is in shambles and with 90,000 infected, mortality rate is 4 percent.  Anez just one among politicial class who has contracted virus and has quarrantined.

The Electoral court has delayed the election as medical experts has suggested a Covid-19 peak in August/ September 2020. October, it has been stated, provides healthier conditions.
The electoral court is  Government appointed, which may be relevant.
https://www.france24.com/en/20200723-bolivian-elections-postponed-again-due-to-covid-19-this-time-until-october
Boliva is hit hard by Covid-19.

https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/andres-oppenheimer/article239675183.html  Anez running and becoming president really isn't that crazy.  She already renegged on her promise not to run.

There were 124 new cases on May 3rd (when the election was originally supposed to be held). There were over 2,000 cases on August 1st (yesterday). If levels were considered too risky back then, it is likely that the election day will again be pushed back, probably by several months given the current trends in Bolivia. That, when combined with the possibility of a second wave still in the air, means it is becoming less and less likely the election will be held in 2020, especially since it is seen as a "special election", meaning there isn't much precedent for when you can and cannot push it back. With Anez so far down in polls, this becomes even more likely, even if not for corrupt reasons, just for the public good. She gains nothing from holding the elections this year during the pandemic, so as we approach the new election date, I suspect another postponement. The rest simply reflects current polling.
The world is moving towards female leaders.
Updating to reflect continued support for Arce. Still thinking election this year is 50-50.
Matching crowd confidence on Arce. Anything over 50/50 is probably too optimistic this far out from Oct.
Decreasing the probability for Áñez, in favor of Mesa, as the polls are showing likely her coming up third. Ncreasing Mesa’s probability by as much.

Polls show Arce at ~30%, Mesa at 20%, Áñez at ~17%. This leads me to these scenarios:
1. Runoff elections between Arce and Áñez with Áñez enjoying support by Mesa. This would lead to Áñez win most likely.
2. Runoff elections between Arce and Mesa with Mesa enjoying support by Áñez. This would lead to Mesa win most likely. Equally likely to the 1 above.
3. Runoff election between Arce and either Mesa or Áñez with Arce still consolidating at above 50%. I believe this to be less likely than the above, as there is a center right momentum in Latin America currently with Brazil etc so I think Bolivia is following the same trajectory. I give Arce majority about 30% max probability.
I will split the rest between a Mesa and Áñez, with more to Mesa.

First, the main issue is whether election will be held in 2020. Recently, it has been postponed for the second time to Oct 2020. It is forecast that pandemic will reach its peak in September 2020. The scheduled election in Oct is dependent on the curve of the pandemic. As of this moment, the chances are that election will not be postponed third time.
Second issue is whether Arce has any chances of being disqualified. It depends on the court ruling, however, the allegation of electoral violation over a statement may not be strong enough.
Hence, in the event, if Arce is not disqualified, he has the backing of the voters with highest rating among the presidential candidates.
Hence, the forecast depends on the pandemic and court ruling, which will become clearer in the following weeks.
I agree... the election in general is in doubt. Not to mention the behind the scenes tomfoolery.
Elections postponed again to October. I'll give them a 50-50 chance of happening this year.
Postponement because of c-19 or using c-19 by Anez to postpone. Arce  polling about 10 pts over Mesa. Evo still influential behind Arce.

Postponement from 03 May 2020 to 06 September 2020 to 18 October as of now.
If COVID-19 in Latin America and Bolivia in particular is the reason behind it, then the latest postponement will not be the last one in a series of postponements; a sense of realism may sip through that elections will not be a good idea in general this year, and Jeanine Áñez will be willing and eager to continue to rule as an acting president into 2021.

Luis Arce ahead on polls with 33.1%
https://www.celag.org/quien-ganara-las-elecciones-en-bolivia/

I started fresh, took the crowd out of consideration, built up a reasonable distribution of probabilities (subjectively but sincerely) and then trimmed back uniformly to total 100%.
That said, the crowd seemed pretty spot on with the information available to us. Áñez and "Someone Else" seemingly have no chance (read: *legitimate* chance,) but oh well, benefit of the doubt here. 
As far as what will happen with C19, I think it is safe to expect an election will be held considering the current local trajectory. If anything, perhaps turnout will take the biggest hit. Or maybe it'll drive turnout. If the health ministry says the risk is too high, I believe the election can be postponed until Jan 2021. From AP "Most researchers agree that “to plan activities such as an election, you must wait for the epidemiological curve of active cases to have a sustained decrease for a period of 14 days, so the date of Sept. 6 is not appropriate,” the committee, made up mostly of doctors, wrote to Salvador Romero, president of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal." ...and "Six of the eight parties in Bolivia’s election race have said they favor a postponement." Then there is postponement via corruption. Via AP "The Movement for Socialism party, which nominated former economy minister Luis Arce as its presidential candidate, wants the election to go ahead as scheduled. Its supporters have warned of street protests if the election is postponed and Arce alleged the Áñez government is using the pandemic as a “pretext to extend itself.”"
Bolivia is in dire need of political leadership and stability. So, this appears to be a no-win situation. I don't think these numbers will budge much. C19 news will likely be the only relevant news.
As it stands: Movimiento Demócrata Social will keep Áñez installed as long as possible, by either postponing or rigging the election (either overtly or covertly.)
If the election is held and held legitimately, Arce is favored to win. ***That said, I will reevaluate and redistribute probabilities closer to election day.*** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Bolivian_general_election#Presidential_candidates

Recent history has an effect on the upcoming elections rather than the particular policies of the challengers.
Carlos Mesa (Centre Right) is the ex-President who reigned in 2005 after failing to resolve the countries discord without resorting to violence.
Mesa is ‘Yesterday’s Man’ with a failure to previously govern. Jeanine Anez (Hard Right) is the interim president put in place by the coup that usurped Morales. She stated in November 2019 that she had no intention of standing in the election for the Presidency.
She has discarded the previous government’s progressive policies and ended the connections with Nicaragua, Cuba and Venezuela.
Her government have gained plaudits for handling the Covid-19 lockdown that would have been eased by the use of the military and police. Carlos Mesa (Socialist) was the Finance Minister in the Morales government prior to the coup.
In democratically elected countries, history shows that the incumbent ruling party lasts about 9 years before ‘losing touch’ with the people that elected them and getting used to power.
Morales Government, while halving extreme poverty and raising the living standards by social spending in his 14 years of being in power, tried to remain in power by changing the constitution with accusations of voter fraud.
There must be an assumption that the socialists are still popular given their past successes in increasing the wealth of the majority of people, but the problem is that of the left being able to unite as a formidable party. I propose that if the left is able to unite, they will prevail.
The hard right will come a close second due to its handling of the coronavirus.
The centre right will come a distant third.
There is a  chance of the election being cancelled at this stage due to Covid-19. The date has been set in law.
